user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer:
```c
static bool
has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING == c->state);
  if (! c->rq.have_chunked_upload)
    return 0 != c->read_buffer_offset;

  /* Chunked upload */
  mhd_assert (0 != c->rq.remaining_upload_size); /* Must not be possible in MHD_CONNECTION_BODY_RECEIVING state */
  if (c->rq.current_chunk_offset == c->rq.current_chunk_size)
  {
    /* 0 == c->rq.current_chunk_size: Waiting the chunk size (chunk header).
       0 != c->rq.current_chunk_size: Waiting for chunk-closing CRLF. */
    return false;
  }
  return 0 != c->read_buffer_offset; /* Chunk payload data in the read buffer */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in the provided function modifies the parameter variable 'c' itself. All uses of 'c' are reads of the object it points to (c->state, c->rq.*, c->read_buffer_offset) and there are no assignments to 'c' (no c = ..., no pointer arithmetic on c, no increment/decrement of c). The mhd_assert macro is defined as ((void)0), so it cannot hide any modification of the parameter. Note that MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 allows modification of the object referred to by a pointer parameter; even if the code modified fields of *c that would be permitted. Because neither the pointer parameter nor the pointer variable is altered in this function, there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 17.8.
